title: Generation of a squamous cell carcinoma mouse model for lineage tracing of BMI1+ cancer stem cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Tissues harvesting
Timing: 2–4 h
        To label BMI1+ CSCs, Bmi1CreER; R26tdTomato mice are injected with tamoxifen
        intraperitoneally at a dose of 225 mg per 1 kg body weight 24 h before
        sacrificing the mice. For in vivo lineage tracing of BMI1+
        CSCs and their progenies, mice are injected with tamoxifen
        intraperitoneally at a dose of 225 mg per 1 kg body weight
        2–6 weeks before ending the experiments.
      
        To label proliferating tumor cells, mice bearing HNSCC are first
        injected intraperitoneally with EdU at a dose of 25 μg/g body weight
        after reaching the experimental endpoint.
      
        90 min after EdU injection, mice are then euthanized using CO2
        asphyxiation.
      
        Use the needles to pin the mouse limbs to the dissection board to secure
        the body. Spray the body with 70% ethanol.
      
        Use forceps to grab the skin and cut a long incision through the midline
        from the chin to the upper chest region of the mouse using scissors.
      
        Gently insert scissors under the skin to separate the skin from the
        underlying tissues.
      
        Once the skin is fully detached, cut and open the skin laterally at the
        chest level and pin the skin with needles to expose the cervical lymph
        nodes (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/604-Fig2.jpg
              Figure 2. Dissection and photographing of mouse HNSCC
            
(A) Dissecting cervical lymph nodes.
(B and C) Tumor lesions on the tongue.
Scale bar for (A and B), 500 μm; Scale bar for (C), 200 μm.
        Carefully excise the lymph nodes with sharp scissors under the Leica EZ4
        Stereo Microscope (Use hemostatic cotton to swab the blood that might
        hinder the identification of the lymph nodes).
      
        Place the lymph nodes into a 15 mL falcon tube filled with 10 mL 4% PFA
        at 22°C–25°C.

After collecting all the lymph nodes, cut the joints on both sides of
        the jaws with a bone scissor. Open the jaws as wide as possible to
        expose the tongue tissues (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). Cut the whole
        tongue using a sharp scissor.
      
        Take photos of the tongue using the Leica EZ4 Stereo Microscope with a
        ruler (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
      
        Put the tongue in the 4% PFA tube mentioned above (The tissue can be
        kept in 4% PFA up to 72 h before over-fixation).
      
        After 24 h, remove PFA and wash the tongue and lymph nodes three times
        with PBS for 30 min at 22°C–25°C. Cut the tongue into halves
        sagittally along the mid-line of the HNSCC lesion. Keep half of the
        lesion for paraffin section and the other half for cryosection.
      
Cryo-section and immunostaining
Timing: 1–2 days
        Discard PBS and pour in 10 mL of 30% sucrose solution in PBS into the
        15 mL tube. Keep the tissue at 4°C for 48 h until the tissue sinks in
        the solution.
      
        Embed the tissue in pre-chilled optimal cutting temperature (OCT)
        compound in an appropriate embedding mold. Freeze on dry ice and store
        tissue at −80°C until sectioning.
      
        Cut the cytosections at a thickness of 8–10 μm using a Leica
        cryostat and collect the sections with Superfrost Slides (Fisher
        Scientific Cat#12-550-15).
      
Let the slides dry for 5 min at 22°C–25°C.
        Fix in 4% PFA for 10 min in a humidified chamber, 200 μL/sample, and
        spread with a new pipette tip (operate in the chemical hood).
      
Wash the slides in PBS for 5 min three times.
        Make blocking buffer (5% Normal Donkey Serum, 1% bovine serum albumin,
        0.2% Triton X-100 in 1 × PBS).
      
        Trace around the sections with a pap pen and add 200–400 μL block
        buffer per slide.

Block in a humidified chamber for 30 min at 22°C–25°C.
        Decant block buffer and add anti-pan-cytokeratin antibodies (1:500,
        Santa Cruz, Cat#sc-8018) or anti-keratin 5 (1:500; BioLegend,
        Cat#905501) diluted in block buffer to each slide (200 μL per slide) and
        cover with a plastic coverslip. Because some hematopoietic cells in
        lymph nodes express BMI1, the sections of cervical lymph nodes need to
        be stained with anti-pan-cytokeratin antibodies to confirm that BMI1+
        CSCs are metastatic tumor cells.
      
Incubate at 40C in a humidified chamber.
        The next day, lift off the coverslip by dipping in PBS until coverslip
        slips off the slide on its own
      
        Place slide into a Coplin jar with 1 × PBS/0.1% Triton x-100 (PBS-T).
        Wash for 5 min.
      
Repeat this wash 2 more times.
        Dilute secondary antibodies in PBS-T 1:200 and add 200–300 μL per
        slide (no coverslip) and incubate at 22°C–25°C in humidified
        chamber for 45 min.
      
        Wash in PBS-T (in a Coplin jar) 3 times (5 min per wash) and then 2
        times in PBS (no Triton)
      
        Dip slide in ddH20 and then add 1–2 drops of
        Vectashield with DAPI (#H-1200-10, Vector Laboratories) and carefully
        place glass coverslip over while avoiding trapping bubbles under the
        slide.
      
Fix slide with nail polish around the coverslip.
        Acquire the images with a fluorescent microscopy running CellSens
        software (Olympus
        http://www.olympus-lifescience.com/en/software/cellsens/[href=http://www.olympus-lifescience.com/en/software/cellsens/]).
      
Paraffin section and H&E staining
Timing: 2–3 days
        Transfer tissue to 70% ethanol for fixation for 14–16 h at
        22°C–25°C.
      
Transfer tissue to 80% ethanol for 30 min at 22°C–25°C.
Transfer tissue to 95% ethanol for 30 min at 22°C–25°C.
        Transfer tissue to 100% ethanol for 30 min at 22°C–25°C. Repeat
        this step twice.
      
        Transfer tissue to Histoclear II for 30 min at 22°C–25°C. Repeat
        this step twice.
      
        Incubate tissue in melted paraffin in 56°C–58°C for 30 min.

After incubation, transfer tissue into a labeled cassette – you can
        leave this indefinitely until ready to embed into molds.
      
Embed and label accordingly.
        Cut the paraffin section at a thickness of 5 μm using a Leica RM2235
        manual microtome and collect the sections with Superfrost Slides (Fisher
        Scientific Cat#12-550-15).
      
        Deparaffinize the sections in Histoclear II for 3 min at
        22°C–25°C. Repeat twice.
      
        Rehydrate the sections into 100% ethanol solution for 1 min at
        22°C–25°C.
      
        Transfer the sections into 95% ethanol solution for 1 min at
        22°C–25°C.
      
        Transfer the sections into 80% ethanol solution for 1 min at
        22°C–25°C.
      
        Transfer the sections into 70% ethanol solution for 1 min at
        22°C–25°C.
      
        Transfer the sections into deionized H2O for 5 min at 22°C–25°C.
      
        Perform H&E staining using a H&E Staining Kit (Abcam, ab245880)
        according to the manufacturer’s guidance.
      
        Mount the slides with Permount Mounting Medium (#SP15-100, Fisher
        Scientific) and a cover slide.
      
Air dry the slides in the chemical hood for 14–16 h.
        Acquire the images with a microscopy running CellSens software (Olympus
        http://www.olympus-lifescience.com/en/software/cellsens/[href=http://www.olympus-lifescience.com/en/software/cellsens/]).
